reasoning: The transcription provides a step-by-step guide on how to make candied citrus peel. The steps are extracted based on the sequence of actions described by Jacques Pepin, from peeling the citrus fruit to candying the peel and optionally coating it with chocolate.
dish_description: Candied citrus peel is a confection made by cooking strips of citrus peel in sugar syrup until they become translucent and then coating them with sugar. They can be enjoyed as a sweet treat or used as a garnish for desserts.

cooking_steps.description: Use a vegetable peeler to take long strips of citrus peel, preferably from grapefruits or oranges, ensuring only the top part of the skin is taken to avoid bitterness.
Blanch the citrus peels in boiling water for about 10 to 15 seconds to remove bitterness, then drain them.
Prepare a syrup by combining 3/4 cup of water with 1/2 cup of sugar in a pot and bring it to a boil.
Cook the citrus peels in the boiling syrup for about 10 to 12 minutes until the syrup reaches the 'break stage,' where it thickens considerably.
Remove the candied peels from the syrup and roll them in granulated sugar to coat them thoroughly.
Allow the sugar-coated peels to dry until they are no longer sticky and have hardened, which can take from 15 minutes to half an hour.
Store the candied peels in a plastic container in the refrigerator to keep them for weeks.
Optionally, dip the candied peels in melted chocolate (dark, milk, or white) and let them cool off on non-stick aluminum foil until the chocolate hardens. These can be kept for about a week.
